name: Dar-us-Sakina
mission: The mission of Dar-us-Sakina is to provide inclusive opportunities for individuals with disabilities in the Muslim community of Houston, while empowerin...
theoryOfChange: Dar-us-Sakina operates within a documented framework that guides its programming in three key service areas: education, support, and community awareness. Their mission is to provide inclusive opportunities and resources to individuals with disabilities and their caregivers in the Muslim community of Houston, with a vision for a community where individuals with disabilities are fully accepted and included. The organization's core values are Compassion, Acceptance, Responsibility, and Empathy. Within their service framework, they offer various programs such as Sakina Sunday School, Teen and Adult life skills programs, an Adult Day Program, support groups, mental health workshops, respite care, and community awareness initiatives through volunteer and internship programs. Charity Navigator also notes their strategic thinking through articulating their mission, vision, and strategic goals, which include expanding their Teen Adult program, investing in capacity building, and building new partnerships.
zakatClaimEvidence: Dar-us-Sakina has a "Zakat Program" and states, "For special needs families in crisis, we are committed to providing comprehensive support through our Zakat Fund." dimension_explanations.alignment: Dar-us-Sakina shows high alignment with donor needs by addressing the urgent requirement for disability inclusion within religious education [3][6]. Its status as a zakat-eligible institution and its track record of supporting families through a dedicated Zakat Fund further strengthens its fit for Muslim donors [10][11].
dimension_explanations.impact: The charity focuses on capacity building through the Sakina Sunday School and internship programs, maintaining a program expense ratio of 72.2% [1][4][5]. While it demonstrates effectiveness in providing specialized Islamic education and caregiver support, the cost per beneficiary is relatively high at approximately $3,948 [9][10].

strengths.detail: The organization maintains a <cite id="1">93/100 overall score from Charity Navigator</cite>, reflecting high standards of transparency and governance.
Dar-us-Sakina holds <cite id="1">15.9 months of working capital</cite>, providing immense stability for its specialized programs.
The charity reports a <cite id="2">72.2% program expense ratio</cite> in its latest filings, ensuring maximum resource allocation to direct services.

strengths_deep_dive: Dar-us-Sakina excels in operational leaness, as evidenced by its <cite id="1">perfect scores of 100 in Culture and Leadership</cite> from Charity Navigator. Their <cite id="2">diversified revenue stream</cite>, which includes <cite id="2">$142,034 in program service revenue</cite> alongside contributions, suggests a sustainable model for growth. Furthermore, the organization maintains <cite id="1">72.2% independent board members</cite>, ensuring objective oversight of its mission to serve the <cite id="6">underserved disability community in Houston</cite>.
rich_narrative.summary: Dar-us-Sakina is a Houston-based non-profit dedicated to providing <cite id="3">inclusive opportunities and Islamic education</cite> for individuals with disabilities. The organization addresses a critical gap in the Muslim community by offering specialized services such as the <cite id="4">Teen and Adult Program (TAP)</cite> and the <cite id="5">Sakina Sunday School</cite>. In 2023, the charity reported <cite id="2">total revenue of $540,354</cite>, representing a significant <cite id="2">3-year revenue CAGR of 24.6%</cite>. Their financial operations are characterized by high efficiency, with <cite id="1">fundraising costs of only $0.13 per $1 raised</cite>. Beyond education, the organization fosters <cite id="6">community awareness and caregiver support</cite>, ensuring a holistic approach to disability inclusion. As a <cite id="11">zakat-eligible institution</cite>, it provides a verified avenue for Muslim donors to fulfill their religious obligations while supporting <cite id="10">families through a dedicated Zakat Fund</cite>.
